etymologies: early 19th century; earliest use found in Horace Wilson (1786–1860), Sanskritist. Partly from Sanskrit śiṣya student, disciple, lit. ‘one to be taught’, use as noun of the gerundive of śas- to teach, instruct

definitions: In Hinduism: a disciple or follower of a guru. Also in extended use: a pupil learning a craft from a master; a younger person who is guided and supported by someone with greater experience or influence.
